title: Paul's Conversion and Early Ministry
description: Follow Paul's transformation from persecutor to preacher, from Damascus to his early ministry years.

steps.note: Paul (then Saul) begins his journey to Damascus with letters from the high priest to arrest Christians.
On the road to Damascus, Paul encounters the risen Christ in a blinding light and is converted.
Ananias heals Paul's blindness and baptizes him. Paul immediately begins preaching in the synagogues.
After facing opposition, Paul escapes Damascus by being lowered in a basket through the city wall.
Paul returns to Jerusalem where Barnabas introduces him to the apostles, vouching for his conversion.
Paul returns to his hometown Tarsus for several years of preparation and ministry.
Barnabas brings Paul to Antioch, where they minister together for a year and the disciples are first called 'Christians'.
Paul and Barnabas deliver famine relief to Jerusalem, completing Paul's preparation for missionary work.

title: First Missionary Journey (46-48 AD)
description: Paul and Barnabas's pioneering journey to Cyprus and Asia Minor, establishing the first Gentile churches.

steps.note: The Holy Spirit calls Paul and Barnabas for missionary work. The church fasts, prays, and sends them out.
Paul and Barnabas travel to the port of Seleucia Pieria and sail to Cyprus.
They arrive in Salamis, Cyprus, and preach in the Jewish synagogues with John Mark assisting.
In Paphos, Paul confronts the sorcerer Elymas and converts the proconsul Sergius Paulus. Paul begins to be called by his Roman name.
They sail to Perga in Pamphylia, where John Mark leaves them and returns to Jerusalem.
In Pisidian Antioch, Paul preaches his first recorded sermon, explaining how Jesus fulfills Old Testament prophecies.
In Iconium, they preach boldly despite opposition, performing signs and wonders.
Paul heals a lame man in Lystra. The crowd thinks they are gods, but later Paul is stoned and left for dead.
In Derbe, they make many disciples and then begin the return journey, strengthening the new churches.
They return to Antioch and report how God had opened the door of faith to the Gentiles.

title: Second Missionary Journey (49-52 AD)
description: Paul's journey with Silas into Europe, establishing churches in Macedonia and Achaia.

steps.note: Start from Antioch, where Paul and Silas began their second journey.
In Lystra, Timothy joins Paul and Silas.
Paul has a vision of a man from Macedonia, calling them to Europe.
In Philippi, Lydia is converted, and Paul and Silas are imprisoned but miraculously freed.
Paul preaches in Thessalonica, facing opposition.
The Bereans are praised for eagerly examining the Scriptures.
Paul preaches on Mars Hill in Athens.
Paul stays in Corinth for a year and a half, meeting Aquila and Priscilla.
Paul makes a brief stop in Ephesus on his way back.
Paul lands in Caesarea.
Paul goes up to Jerusalem to greet the church.
Paul returns to Antioch, completing his second journey.
